application_nickname: ECF 1 - Fairfax County Public Library - Equipment and Services
funding_request_narrative:
Fairfax County Public Library (FCPL) is requesting funding for service on 50 hotspots for circulation to patrons. 

FCPL is a large suburban library system in Northern Virginia, serving a population of 1.2 million people over 400 square miles. FCPL has 400,000 cardholders and Fairfax County Public Schools (FCPS) has 178,000 students. Fairfax County demographics are complex and diverse; 39% or 470,000 of our residents speak a language other than English at home and 34.5% or 61,000 FCPS students participate in the Free and Reduced Lunch Program. 

FCPL is a critical community resource, providing digital tools and access for residents who may not have other options available. We offer 400 public PCs with wired internet access, wifi both inside buildings and in our parking lots, and a small collection of 20 circulating Chromebooks – all free of charge. Our circulating Chromebook collection, launched during the COVID-19 pandemic, has been extremely popular and demonstrates that our community continues to have unmet needs for internet access. Between February and July 2021, on average 70% of the Chromebooks were checked out at any one time. In July 2021, on average 78% of the Chromebooks were checked out at any one time. 

We are applying for funding for 50 Chromebooks and 50 wireless hotspots to circulate together, as 50 individual kits.  We anticipate that 100% of these kits will have circulated within 30 days of deployment.

The two parts of our request are new laptops and new network hardware for our students. These are critical to remote learning for obvious reasons, but each one has specific traits that will be critical to our students' success if we have to return to remote learning.

The laptops we intend to purchase and distribute to our students will be replacing current student devices. The current devices were sufficient for in-school learning, but turned out to be totally insufficient for remote learning. The enhanced processor speed and RAM will enable students to simultaneously run remote learning (Zoom) and whatever educational programs/digital workbooks that they are assigned. Additionally, the new devices have better cameras--something particularly important to the engagement of younger students--and upgraded radio antennas, which allow the devices to take advantage of the higher bandwidth that the routers will be supplying.

The routers will be instrumental in ensuring a smooth connection and appropriate learning environment for the students. The two most common complaints during past remote learning were bad connections to the wifi, and an inability to set up a calm environment that is conducive to learning. The mesh network handles both of these problems. By providing continuous coverage over a large area--and multiple access points so that impenetrable walls can be circumvented--the students can be provided with a strong network that reaches to the quiet corner of their bedroom or study. It became exceedingly clear during remote learning that students learning from the living room or kitchen table--especially when multiple students live in the same home--simply could not focus appropriately; enabling them to have private workspaces will greatly improve their learning capabilities.

Families receiving SNAP benefits are less likely to have the disposable income necessary to have access to at-home internet access.

Both US Census Bureau data for the city of Niagara Falls and published data for the local school district strongly indicate an environment where households are without access to internet connectivity, regardless of household age. The Niagara Falls Public Libraries procurement of 200 hotspots will help close the digital divide and provide library patrons access to internet connectivity when they otherwise would not have access to it.

The WCSD is primarily rural, dominated by national and state forest lands, as well as the foothills of the Allegheny Mountains. That rurality creates a transportation barrier for the district and its residents, characterized by the existence of only two (2) major roadways that can provide quick, easy routes throughout the county and beyond. The remaining roads in the county/district are often hilly, windy routes that must be traveled at slower speeds for safety. This results in student travel times in buses of one hour or more for many of the district’s school bus runs, and a bus fleet that travels over 10,000 miles each day bringing students to and from school. 

 

Those same topographies contribute to an ongoing lack of student and family access to sufficient broadband service, if not Internet service in general, in some of our most rural areas.  The pandemic has created more urgency around the issue of access to broadband as local educational agencies (LEA’s) and students continue to confront the very real possibility of school closures and online instruction at the home. One solution to help students have more access to suitable broadband is to install Wi-Fi, delivered via mobile broadband service, in WCSD school buses for use by students during their already long drive times.     

 

The WCSD sent a survey to each of its families at the end of the 2019-2020 school year, when the pandemic began, to provide information on the barriers to online learning present in district homes. Sixty percent (60%) of families responded to the survey and district administrators contacted non-respondents via phone. Those efforts yielded a better than 95% response rate to the survey.     

 

Parents were asked what barriers existed in the home that would keep students from doing online work if schools continued to be closed in the fall.  Parents were able to select multiple items, and among the choices were five items, listed below, related to computers at home and access to the internet at home:    

We do not have a computer 
We do not have enough computers for every child   
We have a computer, but it is too old and slow to do online work   
We don't have the Internet at our house   
We have the Internet, but it is too slow to do online work   
 

Responses to the survey demonstrated that the district had approximately 1109 students who either lacked sufficient broadband access in the home or had no access to Internet service in the home at all. This represents 28% of the total WCSD student population. 

 

With that data, the district is proposing the installation of mobile broadband equipment in the majority of its bus fleet. The proposed equipment will require the use of two separate mobile broadband providers given the large distances covered by district buses, which frequently involve crossing from one carrier coverage area to another. The mobile broadband signal will be converted to Wi-Fi on each bus to support the academic needs of the students during the trip to and from school. Students will then have the ability to read school material, do homework, and other school-related activities to compensate for the barriers that may exist in the home. 

This is the funding request to support the cost of mobile broadband services to each bus.

funding_request_narrative:
Our district has a 1:1 device program in place for grades 6-12 and we are a Google Enterprise District. On 3/13/20 we went fully remote. Our 763 6th-9th grade students were prepared due to the 1:1 device program in place. Their devices all met the Google recommended guidelines for large Google Meets and presentations which were required for their remote learning. At the same time, we had 581 PK-5th grade students that needed devices for remote learning.  We were able to provide 23 Dell Latitude 3310 devices to students at the PK level. These devices exceeded Google recommended guidelines for large Google Meets. We provided various model Chromebooks to 558 K-5 students. Unfortunately, these models (Acer/Lenovo N2x) performed poorly during this time with many students experiencing drops and freezes while attempting to join their respective Google Meets. The models indeed did not meet Google's recommendations with such items as 4GB RAM. These devices had only 2GB RAM for example. 
We utilized SQL reporting to show the number of PK-5 students who were assigned these devices (Attached without students' names) This file shows 558 Acer/Lenovo Chromebook assignments that did not meet Google recommendations. These models consistently showed high resource utilization in the mid to upper 90% range as shown in Google Meets Quality Reporting Tool. It is our intent to request a total of 310 devices that we can provide to our PK-5 students so that they will be equipped for remote learning as required. We will be able to repurpose available devices for the remaining 295 PK-5th grade students that will meet, or exceed, Google's Meet recommendations. It is our intent to ensure that these students will be equipped for remote learning as required. We plan on storing these requested devices within our schools and to make them readily available for the corresponding students during the regular school days on campus. If the district must go to remote learning full-time, then these devices will go with the students to their homes.

funding_request_narrative:
The Tampa-Hillsborough County Public Library (THPL) will be requesting 250 Chromebooks, part# 16W64UT#ABA (11.6" 32GB Chromebook 11A G8). This will include a 3-year manufactures warranty, Google licenses allowing the library's IT team to manage laptops remotely to ensure patron compliance with our laptop use policies, and "white glove" installation services. These laptops will be used as a pilot laptop lending program at 2 of the library's 27 branches in order to close the homework gap and bridge the digital divide in our communities.

THPL seeks to meet the technology access needs of its 1.4 million residents. This project endeavors close the homework gap and bridge the digital divide in our communities through the purchase of 250 circulating laptops that will help library customers connect to the internet and access much-needed resources from home. THPL connects individuals to workforce skills, educational tools, and crucial government resources in a county where 15.3% of residents live below the poverty line. According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Hillsborough County saw a low of 2.5% unemployment in December 2019. By March 2020, when Florida’s first case of Covid-19 was reported here in Hillsborough County, the unemployment rate significantly increased to 4.2%, peaking at 12.3% the following month. Local and state orders related to COVID-19 closed most non-essential businesses, all Hillsborough County schools, and many government services, including all 27 library branches. Furthermore, childcare facilities were required to limit their capacity, which added the additional concerns of childcare and at-home schooling for thousands of families which revealed how ill equipped some communities were when faced with online learning. Although public schools have resumed in-person classes, many parents are considering virtual alternatives, and the students who participate in face-to-face instruction also need internet-connected devices to complete their course assignments. According to the Florida Department of Education, 58% of the more than 200,000 Hillsborough County Public School students are economically disadvantaged and may not have the resources to meet their educational needs. These individuals and families need internet-capable devices for job searching and school work, but U.S. Census figures show that a large number of households did not have these services even prior to the loss of income related to COVID-19. 

THPL understands that access to opportunity is dependent upon digital literacy and enables fair access to public technology. Hillsborough County libraries encourage skill development and improve workforce readiness. They serve as active, dynamic community centers that contribute to economically sound communities and provide vital entrepreneur and small business support. Many residents depend on libraries and other government service centers for reliable, free access to the internet and public computers for their personal and professional needs. In fiscal year 2019, patrons accessed library WiFi 3,889,030 times and signed into the library’s public computers 699,336 times. Both figures reflect an increase from the previous year. The Library has a popular, well-established hotspot lending program, and in fiscal year 2019, 120 WiFi hotspots were borrowed 1,224 times for a two-week checkout period. During extended library closures in response to COVID-19, THPL established Park & Surf WiFi Zones in the parking lots of 9 branches in targeted areas of the county, and in June 2020, customers utilized those WiFi zones 90,890 times. This usage level equals more than one-third of the total connections in June 2019.

THPL finds this to be supporting evidence for the establishment of a laptop lending program to address the technology needs of the community which would well compliment the library's existing internet connectivity services like the hotspot lending program and Park & Surf WiFi Zones.

funding_request_narrative:
The WCSD is primarily rural, dominated by national and state forest lands, as well as the foothills of the Allegheny Mountains. That rurality creates a transportation barrier for the district and its residents, characterized by the existence of only two (2) major roadways that can provide quick, easy routes throughout the county and beyond. The remaining roads in the county/district are often hilly, windy routes that must be traveled at slower speeds for safety. This results in student travel times in buses of one hour or more for many of the district’s school bus runs, and a bus fleet that travels over 10,000 miles each day bringing students to and from school. 

 

Those same topographies contribute to an ongoing lack of student and family access to sufficient broadband service, if not Internet service in general, in some of our most rural areas.  The pandemic has created more urgency around the issue of access to broadband as local educational agencies (LEA’s) and students continue to confront the very real possibility of school closures and online instruction at the home. One solution to help students have more access to suitable broadband is to install Wi-Fi, delivered via mobile broadband service, in WCSD school buses for use by students during their already long drive times.     

 

The WCSD sent a survey to each of its families at the end of the 2019-2020 school year, when the pandemic began, to provide information on the barriers to online learning present in district homes. Sixty percent (60%) of families responded to the survey and district administrators contacted non-respondents via phone. Those efforts yielded a better than 95% response rate to the survey.     

 

Parents were asked what barriers existed in the home that would keep students from doing online work if schools continued to be closed in the fall.  Parents were able to select multiple items, and among the choices were five items, listed below, related to computers at home and access to the internet at home:    

We do not have a computer 
We do not have enough computers for every child   
We have a computer, but it is too old and slow to do online work   
We don't have the Internet at our house   
We have the Internet, but it is too slow to do online work   
 

Responses to the survey demonstrated that the district had approximately 1109 students who either lacked sufficient broadband access in the home or had no access to Internet service in the home at all. This represents 28% of the total WCSD student population. 

 

With that data, the district is proposing the installation of mobile broadband equipment in the majority of its bus fleet. The proposed equipment will require the use of two separate mobile broadband providers given the large distances covered by district buses, which frequently involve crossing from one carrier coverage area to another. The mobile broadband signal will be converted to Wi-Fi on each bus to support the academic needs of the students during the trip to and from school. Students will then have the ability to read school material, do homework, and other school-related activities to compensate for the barriers that may exist in the home. 

This is the funding request to support the cost of mobile broadband services to each bus.
